awd_titl_txt: Morton Arboretum REU site:  Integrated tree science in the Anthropocene
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the Morton Arboretum, located in Lisle, IL, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019- 2021. Research focuses on the use of trees as model systems to gain a broad understanding of evolution, ecology, conservation, and management in natural and built environments.  The Center for Tree Science (CTS) researchers will guide students through the scientific process using an integrative approach, where different scientific fields are combined on a focal topic (trees, in this case) to conduct solution-based science. This REU will foster intellectual development, critical thinking, independence, self-confidence, and perseverance that will benefit students as they pursue a career in any field. Field trips, science communication training, and networking events with regional REU sites are highlights of the program. Students present their results at a research symposium. Applications are recruited nationally, through listservs and job boards. Applications are encouraged from NSF-recognized under-represented minority (URM) students both locally and nationally, students from colleges where research opportunities are limited, and outstanding beginning students (first and second year).

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily URM students, students from limited-research institutions, and beginning students, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will go on to present their work at national scientific conferences. Successful projects can be continued the following year through fellowships offered by the Center for Tree Science.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.mortonarb.org/reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Chuck Cannon at ccannon@mortonarb.org) or the co-PI (Dr. Silvia Alvarez-Clare at salvarezclare@mortonarb.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU program site based at the Morton Arboretum in the western Chicago suburbs creates a unique opportunity for students to pursue a research project in tree science that addresses important ecological and evolutionary questions in both natural and built systems.  Hosted by the Center for Tree Science (CTS), a multidisciplinary team of seven lab groups based at the Arboretum, provides a strong educational environment for the program’s theme of  “Integrated tree science in the Anthropocene”.  The cohort of students not only learn about a wide range of research fields and techniques, the botanic garden setting enables interaction and learning from the many departments and audiences that intersect with the arboretum’s mission.  Trees and forests are vital elements of a sustainable and healthy future for people and the planet.  Our program offers students the opportunity to become immersed in a community of researchers, arborists, science educators, volunteers, and arboretum members all focused on a singular mission of helping trees meet the challenges of the future and improve people’s lives along the way. 


In total, the program supported 42 students, including 28 directly funded by the REU grant, while the remaining 14 participants were funded primarily through CTS internal funds, supplementary REU grants to existing NSF projects, and the new NSF-Research Experience for Postbaccalaureate Student program.  Additionally, 32 mentors from 8 institutions have contributed to the program during the three year grant period, including peer-to-peer mentoring by early career research assistants and other interns in the lab groups.  The student cohort also interacted with other departments and programs active during the summer at the Arboretum, including staff and interns in Living Collections, youth volunteers in Science camp, and science communication staff in Marketing.  We also participated in exchange visits with the Chicago Botanic Garden REU program, where our students shared their experiences and research projects and the entire group received professional training on topics like resume writing, applying to graduate school, and rounds of ‘elevator pitches’ about their research.


All of the students successfully completed independent research projects, in collaboration with one of our resident scientists and their group of researchers.  These projects involved working through all of the phases of project development, from conception to sample design and collection and analysis and presentation.  Given the multidisciplinary nature of our research team, student projects involved research on soil and forest ecology, evolutionary biology, conservation genetics, basic tree biology, and drone technologies.  A highlight of the program is always the final symposium where the students present their findings and interpretations.  This event also included well-known and inspirational speakers (all women) related to their professional and personal journeys in science.  We have also offered a Career Day discussion with a panel of professionals from several different departments at the Arboretum so that the students are aware of the many different paths in tree-related careers.


One of the particularly successful outcomes of the REU program at the Morton Arboretum is the frequent long-term engagement between students and mentors, following the ten week period.  In order to facilitate these lasting relationships, the CTS offers Research Experience Extension Fellowships to allow the student to follow through on the project and even return in the following year to collect another season of data or finalize analyses for publication.  We have supported at least 10 REEFs and almost all of these students have gone onto graduate school in a tree related research field.


Additionally, during the COVID pandemic of 2020, we chose to proceed with a virtual program, after the widespread quarantine conditions were imposed.  This decision required a radical adjustment in our program and the development of educational and research experiences that the students could perform in their own homes.  Overall, the program was successful and we learned a great deal about managing and engaging students under remote conditions.  Our program also contributed to a national assessment of these types of remote learning programs, resulting in two large collaborative publications reporting upon the strengths and weaknesses of these programs.  The lasting lesson from this experience of holding a virtual program was that the in-person element of our REU program was irreplaceable and essential.  Given the uncertainty of the pace and reliable resolution of the COVID quarantine conditions, we chose to defer in 2021 and wait until normal conditions would allow us to confidently hold the program in-person again.  Due to the cost savings during the virtual program in 2020, we offered a smaller program for 4 REU, 2 REPS, and several Student Conservation Association interns in 2023.
